sentences: Jordan Rakei (born 1992) is a New Zealand-Australian musician, singer, songwriter and record producer currently based in London, United Kingdom.
section: N/A

sentences: Rakei has also released and performed under the moniker Dan Kye.
section: N/A
== Early life ==

sentences: Early life ==
section: == Early life ==

sentences: Rakei was born in 1992 in the small town of Tokoroa on New Zealand's North Island to a New Zealander mother and a Pacific Islander father, a Māori from the Cook Islands.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: At the age of three, Rakei and his family moved to Brisbane, Australia.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: He lived in Brisbane until he made the move to London in 2015.
section: == Early life ==

== Music career == | === 2013–2016: Early career and debut album ===

sentences: Rakei's first releases were Live at Recording Oasis and Franklin's Room EPs in 2013, self-released, aged 21 years old.
section: == Music career == | === 2013–2016: Early career and debut album ===

sentences: Less than a year later in 2014, Rakei releases, Groove Curse EP, was the first release on the Soul Has No Tempo label.
section: == Music career == | === 2013–2016: Early career and debut album ===

sentences: Less than a year after this EP, he made the move to London.
section: == Music career == | === 2013–2016: Early career and debut album ===

sentences: After working with artists such as FKJ and Tom Misch, in December 2015 he was part of a Grammy nomination for his work on Disclosure's track "Masterpiece", released on their 2015 album Caracal.
section: == Music career == | === 2013–2016: Early career and debut album ===

sentences: Rakei released his debut album Cloak through his own label, 4101 Records on 3 June 2016.
section: == Music career == | === 2013–2016: Early career and debut album ===

sentences: Later that year, he unveiled his dancefloor alias Dan Kye, and released his first EP, titled Joy, Ease, Lightness, on Rhythm Section records.
section: == Music career == | === 2013–2016: Early career and debut album ===

sentences: Wallflower and subsequent releases ===
section: == Music career == | === 2017–2020: Wallflower and subsequent releases ===

sentences: On 6 June 2017, it was announced that Rakei had signed to Ninja Tune records and would be releasing his next album with them.
section: == Music career == | === 2017–2020: Wallflower and subsequent releases ===

sentences: With this announcement came the release of his new single "Sorceress".
section: == Music career == | === 2017–2020: Wallflower and subsequent releases ===

sentences: Later that month, he made his Glastonbury Festival live debut on the Pussy Parlure stage.
section: == Music career == | === 2017–2020: Wallflower and subsequent releases ===

sentences: On 22 September 2017, Wallflower was released on Ninja Tune.
section: == Music career == | === 2017–2020: Wallflower and subsequent releases ===

sentences: Wallflower was later shortlisted for Best Australian Album in the 2017 Australian Music Prize.
section: == Music career == | === 2017–2020: Wallflower and subsequent releases ===

sentences: A tour of North America in spring 2018 included a performance at SXSW Festival and a live session for Jason Bentley's radio show on KCRW.
section: == Music career == | === 2017–2020: Wallflower and subsequent releases ===

sentences: In 2018, Rakei released the single "Wildfire", released on 10 May 2018, and also provided the vocals on the 2018 Nightmares on Wax track "Typical".
section: == Music career == | === 2017–2020: Wallflower and subsequent releases ===

sentences: On 26 February 2019, Rakei released "Mind's Eye", the first single from his then unannounced third album.
section: == Music career == | === 2017–2020: Wallflower and subsequent releases ===

sentences: On 23 April 2019, Rakei announced this new album, titled Origin, and released a new single from it, "Say Something".
section: == Music career == | === 2017–2020: Wallflower and subsequent releases ===

sentences: The album was released on 14 June 2019.
section: == Music career == | === 2017–2020: Wallflower and subsequent releases ===

sentences: Rakei supported the record with a series on music festival dates in Summer 2019 and then began a subsequent world tour, beginning that August in Brisbane and ending in November 2019 in Brooklyn, New York.
section: == Music career == | === 2017–2020: Wallflower and subsequent releases ===

sentences: During the tour, he recorded a set for NPR Music's "Tiny Desk Concerts" series which was published online on 13 January 2020.

sentences: In September 2021, Rakei's fourth studio album What We Call Life was released, preceded by four singles.

sentences: Rakei said the album is his "most vulnerable and intimate album to date"; something that he attributes to listening to singer-songwriters like Laura Marling, Scott Matthews, Joni Mitchell and John Martyn while writing the record.
